pages.title: The Art of Brewing
pages.text: Fermentation is a very natural process - things take time and care. Since there never is a fully controlled environment there are a lot of variables.$(br)You can follow the recipe to the point, or play around. Fermentation is Art!

pages.title: Outside Influences
pages.text: $(li)Time: It takes time for the barrel to influence the contents. Most beverages get more intense and even additional effects, when given more time than strictly required$(li)Temperature: The hotter it is, the more of your precious content simply evaporates over time. This is called the Angel's Share

$(li)Humidity: The more humid the air, the more water evaporates in comparison to alcohol, making the drink stronger$(li)Water Share: An increased rate of ingredients to water is a fine balance, but one to be played with. More thickness makes the drink ferment faster, albeit at the cost of shorter status effect durations

pages.title: Malt Beer
pages.text: Malt beer is filling and tastes both sweet and savory. What a nice combination.

pages.title: Myceylon Apple Juice
pages.text: Sweet with a Cinnamon finish

pages.title: Safety Question
pages.text: The $(item)Titration Barrel$() is capable of brewing alcoholic drinks. If you are old enough to consume alcohol in your country, you can press the button below to unlock these recipes.$(br)If not don't worry - you won't miss anything important.

pages.title: Beers
pages.text: In addition to Haste it can grant a bit of Saturation, depending on how long it fermented.
Just... don't brew them too long or they will shift and end up tasting awful.

pages.title: Gin
pages.text: Made from $(l:cuisine/amaranth)Amaranth$(/l), grants $(thing)Luck$() and $(thing)Haste$().

pages.title: Rum
pages.text: A strong taste, made even more intense via the influence of the colored wood, grants $(thing)Absorption$() and $(thing)Resistance$().

pages.title: Mead
pages.text: The large amount of sugar in honey is perfect for fermentation. The result is a strong, although still sweet drink.

pages.title: Apple Cider
pages.text: Fermented apples, usually sweet and sparkly, with a slight note of sour - if you do not forget to tap it soon enough.

pages.title: Golden Ciders
pages.text: Way more potent than their common counterpart. Won't go bad over time and taste glorious for sure.

pages.title: Berry Cider
pages.text: A much more fruity cider than from apples. The glowy variant seems to ferment a bit quicker, but also... makes you glow. Hmm.

pages.title: Berry Liquor
pages.text: Berries can also be used for liquor. Way more viscous, sweet and strong, but takes longer to ferment.

pages.title: Mint Drinks
pages.text: $(italic)Liquid Luck

pages.title: Vodka
pages.text: Only gets stronger with age. Just one question: How deadly do you want it?

pages.title: Tequila
pages.text: Does only get stronger with age. Tastes like a bar fight.

pages.title: Moonshine
pages.text: Lies wonderfully light in the mouth. A gentle, sweetish burn, which lets you forget your worries for a bit. The things that worry you will forget you for a bit, too$().$(br2)$(italic)Tastes like walking on the moon.

pages.title: Myceylon Liquor
pages.text: More spicy than it looks.

pages.title: Spiked Mullet Wine
pages.text: An interesting combination of all things Deeper Down. Best drunk when still hot!

pages.title: Pure Alcohol
pages.text: Your memory isn't always up to snuff. Somehow you ended up with this bottle. Definitely got a little stronger than planned...$(br)More to disinfect than to drink.
